sentence: Tibi autem, qui sapis, quam potest denuntio ipsi mihi indices quid ex eis cognoveris, ne possis infitiari dixisse, quae  dixeris.
gold: But I offer you a serious caution that you tell me directly what you have gained from those sacrifices, since I know, so that you will not be able to deny having spoken to me.

sentence: sapientia enim doctrinae secundum nomen est eius et non multis est manifesta quibus autem agnita est permanet usque ad conspectum Dei
gold: For the wisdom of doctrine is according to her name, and she is not manifest unto many, but with them to whom she is known, she continueth even to the sight of God.

llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: For the wisdom of teaching is according to its name, and it is not manifest to many, but to those to whom it is known, it remains until the sight of God.
gpt-4o-mini: For wisdom is the name of teaching and is not clear to many; to those who have recognized it, it remains until the presence of God.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: Wisdom is the knowledge of doctrine, according to its name, and it is not manifest to many, but to those who have known it, it remains until the sight of God.

sentence: Qui dum anima nondum exspirata concidisset, et impetu facto in cubiculum ex suspicione medicus familiaresque continere atque vulnus obligare coepissent, ipse suis manibus vulnus crudelissime divellit atque animo praesenti se interemit.
gold: He had fallen down, yet he was still inhaling air at the time when his physician and a few individuals from his residence, suspecting an issue, entered the bedroom forcefully and began to stop the bleeding and wrap the wound. Nevertheless, using his hands, he reopened the injury with complete mercilessness and decisively put an end to himself.
gpt-4o: When he had collapsed while still not having drawn his last breath, and his doctor and family members, rushing into the room out of suspicion, began to restrain him and bind the wound, he, with his own hands, brutally tore the wound apart and, with a resolute mind, took his own life.
llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: While he had not yet fallen, his life not having breathed out, and the physician and his attendants, rushing into the bedroom from suspicion, had begun to hold him and bind the wound, he himself tore the wound open most cruelly with his own hands and killed himself with a steady purpose.
gpt-4o-mini: While his soul had not yet breathed its last, and with a sudden rush the doctor and his family began to contain him out of suspicion and to bind his wound, he cruelly tore the wound apart with his own hands and took his life with a present mind.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: While his soul had not yet departed, and the doctor and his family had begun to bind the wound in haste, he himself cruelly tore the wound open with his own hands and ended his life.

sentence: Quo adhuc superstite, sed gravissima infirmitate ab administrando episcopatu prohibito, duo sunt pro illo, Aecci, et Baduuini, electi et consecrati episcopi: ex quo usque hodie provincia illa duos habere solet episcopos.

sentence: strictas trepida cervice secures horrebat Libys, ac summissis ordine palmis orantes veniam iurabant irrita pacta haec Eryce e summo spectabat laeta Dione.
gold: With their necks bowed, the Libyans shrank in fear of the bare axes, extending their hands together in a plea for forgiveness. They swore to a treaty they had no intention of observing. Meanwhile, Dione watched the spectacle from the heights of Eryx, filled with joy.
gpt-4o: The trembling Libyan was dreading the poised axes at his neck, and with their palms raised in order, they were praying for pardon and swearing that the agreements were void. From the heights of Eryx, joyful Dione watched these events.
llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: The Libyan trembled at the axes held rigid on the trembling neck, and with palms lowered in order, praying, they swore to a pardon for the broken agreements. Joyful Dione watched these things from the top of Eryx.
gpt-4o-mini: The frightened Libyan trembled at the strict axes, and with hands lowered in order, they swore, pleading for mercy, that these agreements were void, while happy Dione looked down from the heights of Eryx.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: Libya trembled with a stiff neck, and with lowered hands in order, she prayed for pardon, swearing that these oaths were vain, while joyful Diana looked on from the highest point.

sentence: Qua contentus morum severitudine meus Pythias ac mihi ut abirem suadens, Sufficit mihi, o Luci, inquit seniculi tanta haec contumelia.
gold: With this exhibition of strict moral principles, my companion Pythias suggested that it was best for me to depart, declaring, "Lucius, I am content with having justifiably reprimanded the elderly gentleman in the manner that I did."

llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: Content with this severity of manners, my Pythias, urging me to depart, said, "It is enough for me, O Lucius, that the old man has suffered such an insult."
gpt-4o-mini: Due to the strictness of the moral teaching, my Pythias, as if urging me to leave, it is enough for me, oh Lucius, says the old man, this great insult.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: It is enough for me, O Lucius, that my Pythias, content with the severity of my character, advises me to leave.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: But the son of God has no mother of shame; and even the one he appears to have, he did not marry.

sentence: vociferans, pulsis vivendi e pectore curis: speravi sceptra Ausoniae pepigique, sub armis si dexter Poenis deus et Fortuna fuisset, ut Capuam Iliaci migrarent regna Quirini.
gold: He told the gathered senate that they should not count on Hannibal to rescue them. "I had hoped," he yelled, "that we would be in charge of Italy; and I made a promise that if the armies of Carthage were lucky, the Trojan Quirinus's empire would be relocated to Capua."

sentence: Caesar, cum septimam legionem, quae iuxta constiterat, item urgeri ab hoste vidisset, tribunos militum monuit ut paulatim sese legiones coniungerent et conversa signa in hostes inferrent.
gold: Caesar, upon noticing that the enemy was also heavily attacking the seventh legion situated beside him, instructed the soldier's tribunes to slowly merge the legions together and attack the enemy with two fronts.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: Caesar, seeing that the seventh legion, which was standing nearby, was also being pressed by the enemy, advised the tribunes of the soldiers to gradually join the legions and turn their standards against the enemy.

sentence: At Iugurtha, cognita vanitate atque inperitia legati, subdole eius augere amentiam, missitare supplicantis legatos, ipse quasi vitabundus per saltuosa loca et tramites exercitum ductare.
gold: Jugurtha, nonetheless, fully cognizant of the foolishness and incompetence of the commander in charge, shrewdly exacerbated his foolishness and continuously dispatched imploring messengers to him, whilst he himself, as though seeking to evade a confrontation, led his army through wooded areas and narrow roads.

sentence: Salinator vero quattuor atque triginta tribus inter aerarios referre non dubitavit, cum se damnassent, postea consulem et censorem fecissent, praetexuitque causam, quia necesse esset eas alterutro facto crimine temeritatis aut periurii teneri.
gold: But Salinator did not hesitate to assign thirty-four tribes to the lowest category. He did this because they had elected him Consul and Censor, even though they had condemned him earlier. Salinator justified his action by stating that the tribes were either guilty of irresponsibility or perjury if they did not take one of these actions.
gpt-4o: Salinator, however, did not hesitate to register four and thirty-three among the arrials, when they had condemned him, later made him consul and censor, and he alleged as the reason that it would be necessary for them to be held liable on the charge of rashness or perjury in either case.
llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: But Salinator did not hesitate to return thirty-four tribes to the list of aerarii, since they had condemned him and afterwards made him consul and censor, and he alleged as a reason that they must necessarily be guilty of either rashness or perjury in one of the two actions.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: He did not hesitate to refer the four and thirty tribunes to the aerarii, when they had condemned him, afterwards made him consul and censor, and pleaded his case, because it was necessary to hold them guilty of either temerity or perjury.

sentence: urit enim lini campum seges, urit avenae, urunt Lethaeo perfusa papavera somno: sed tamen alternis facilis labor, arida tantum ne saturare fimo pingui pudeat sola neve effetos cinerem immundum iactare per agros.
gold: For the ground becomes parched due to cultivation of flax, oats and Lethes slumber steeped poppies. However, the toil can be eased by simply changing crops, provided that one is not ashamed of fertilizing the dried-out fields with rich dung and scattering grimy ashes over the exhausted soil.
gpt-4o: For the flax crop scorches the field, the oat scorches, and the poppies soaked with Lethean sleep also scorch; yet the labor is easier in alternation, provided you are not ashamed to enrich the dry soil only with rich manure or to spread impure ashes over the exhausted fields.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: Because we feel a living sense to be present throughout the body and see the whole to be animal, if some force suddenly strikes the middle with a swift blow and separates the two parts, the vital force will undoubtedly be divided and separated from the body at the same time.

sentence: Caesar paulisper ad spem erectus, dein fesso corpore, ubi finis aderat, adsistentis amicos in hunc modum adloquitur: Si fato concederem, iustus mihi dolor etiam adversus deos esset, quod me parentibus, liberis, patriae intra iuventam praematuro exitu raperent: nunc scelere Pisonis et Plancinae interceptus ultimas preces pectoribus vestris relinquo: referatis patri ac fratri, quibus acerbitatibus dilaceratus, quibus insidiis circumventus miserrimam vitam pessima morte finierim.
gold: For a moment, Caesar regained his hope. Then, his powers weakened and he spoke to his friends, while standing at his bedtime just before the end, with the following declaration, "If I were dying a natural death, I would have had justifiable grievance against Heaven for taking me away from my parents, children, and country through a premature end in the prime of my life. Now, as I am being cut off due to the treachery of Piso and Plancina, I entrust my last prayers to the care of your hearts. Convey to my father and my brother the agonies that I endured and the betrayals that surrounded me before I ended the most tragic of all lives with the most despicable of all deaths."

sentence: Itaque, qui post Dareum victum hariolos et vates consulere desierat, rursus ad superstitionem, humanarum mentium ludibrium, revolutus, Aristandrum, cui credulitatem suam addixerat, explorare eventum rerum sacrificiis iubet.

sentence: Si pedites suis auxilium ferant atque in eo morentur, iter facere non posse; si, id quod magis futurum confidat, relictis impedimentis suae saluti consulant, et usu rerum necessariarum et dignitate spoliatum iri.
gold: If the infantry were forced to take over for the cavalry and were delayed in doing so, the march would not succeed. When he was being pursued for death, he locked himself in a chamber that had recently been plastered with lime and sand. He then set fire to create a potent vapor from the plaster. sentence: Multa enim falsa de me audierunt, multa ad eos improbi detulerunt; quorum commoda, ut vos optimi testes estis, semper ego sententia, auctoritate, oratione firmavi: sed credunt improbis, credunt turbulentis, credunt suis.

sentence: Solam divi Augusti mentem tantae molis capacem: se in partem curarum ab illo vocatum experiendo didicisse quam arduum, quam subiectum fortunae regendi cuncta onus.

gpt-4o: Only the mind of the divine Augustus was capable of such a great task: he learned by experience, having been called by him to share in his duties, how arduous and subject to fortune the burden of ruling everything was.
llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: Only the divine mind of Augustus was capable of such a great burden; he himself, having been called by Augustus to share his cares, had learned by experience how arduous, how subject to fortune, was the weight of ruling all things.
gpt-4o-mini: Only the mind of the divine Augustus, capable of such a great burden: having learned by experience that it is how hard, how subject to fortune to govern all burdens, called by him to share in cares.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: I have learned by experience how difficult, how subject to the whims of fortune, is the burden of governing everything.

sentence: Quas Tannonius ille cum utriusque sexus genitalia intellegi vellet, sed eloqui propter infantiam causidicus summus nequiret, multum ac diu haesitato tandem virile marinum nescio qua circumlocutione male ac sordide nominavit; sed enim feminal nullo pacto repperiens munditer dicere ad mea scripta confugit et quodam libro meo legit: interfeminium tegat et femoris obiectu et palmae velamento.
gold: Tannonius intended this to refer to the sexual organs of both males and females but, due to being too shy to say the words explicitly, this skilled lawyer hesitated for a long time and used a strange euphemism. sentence: Dignitatem nostram a Vespasiano inchoatam, a Tito auctam, a Domitiano longius provectam non abnuerim: sed incorruptam fidem professis neque amore quisquam et sine odio dicendus est.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: I would not disown the dignity begun by Vespasian, increased by Titus, and furthered by Domitian: but one who has professed an uncorrupted faith is to be spoken of neither with love nor with hatred.

sentence: Accipiet ergo aliquando Capitolium non mimicos currus nec falsae simulacra victoriae, sed imperatorem veram ac solidam gloriam reportantem, pacem tranquillitatem et tam confessa hostium obsequia, ut vincendus nemo fuerit.

gpt-4o-mini: Therefore, at some time the Capitol will receive not the mimic chariots nor false representations of victory, but the emperor carrying true and solid glory, peace, tranquility, and such acknowledged submission of enemies that no one will need to be conquered.

sentence: Nam priores eius orationes non carent vitiis antiquitatis: lentus est in principiis, longus in narrationibus, otiosus circa excessus; tarde commovetur, raro incalescit; pauci sensus apte et cum quodam lumine terminantur.

sentence: Patres conscripti, Micipsa pater meus moriens mihi praecepit ut regni Numidiae tantummodo procurationem existumarem meam, ceterum ius et imperium eius penes vos esse; simul eniterer domi militiaeque quam maxumo usui esse populo Romano, vos mihi cognatorum, vos adfinium loco ducerem: si ea fecissem, in vostra amicitia exercitum, divitias, munimenta regni me habiturum.
gold: Members of the Senate, on his deathbed, my father Micipsa instructed me to remember that I was responsible solely for overseeing the Numidian kingdom's governance, while you possessed the rightful power and authority. Additionally, he urged me to exert effort in aiding the Roman people both in peacetime and during conflicts, and to consider you as my own family. sentence: ultima legati defleta dolore querella est Palladiis quod farra focis, vel quod stipis ipsis virginibus castisque choris alimenta negentur, Vestales solitis fraudentur sumptibus ignes.
gold: The deputy is crying and expressing his sadness as his final complaint about the fact that the sacrificial grain is being denied to the altars of Pallas, grants are given to the Vestals, and upkeep to the pure choirs, thus depriving Vesta's fires of their usual maintenance.
gpt-4o: The last lament of the envoy was bewailed with sorrow that grain was denied to the hearths of Pallas, or that food was denied to the maidens themselves and their chaste dances; that the Vestal fires were deprived of their usual expenses.

gpt-4o-mini: The last of the legates is mourned with sorrow; it is lamentable to the Palladins that the grain is denied to the hearths, or that the offerings are denied to the virgins themselves and to the chaste choirs, that the Vestals are cheated of their usual expenses for the fires.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: The last complaint of the ambassadors is that the Palladians are being deprived of their last fire, or that the sacred fire is being denied to the chaste choirs of virgins, and the Vestals are being defrauded of their accustomed expenses.

sentence: at multo ducis exemplum clamore secuti involvunt atra telorum moenia nube.

sentence: septimus hebdomadi venit superaddere sextae hunc numerum Christus, placidum qui conficitannum cuncta remittentem contractibus inlaqueata multimodis, hominemque hominis de mortelevantem.
gold: Seventh, Christ arrived to complete the sixth cycle of seven with the necessary number to bring about a year of peace. This year releases all things that were previously held captive by contracts of all kinds, and liberates humanity from the death imposed by other humans.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: The seventh day comes to add to the sixth number Christ, the peaceful one who completes all, remitting contracts bound in many ways, and raising man from the death of man.

sentence: Qui inter alia inenarrabilium scelerum facta, quae historicus eorum Gildus flebili sermone describit, et hoc addebant, ut numquam genti Saxonum sive Anglorum secum Brittaniam incolenti, verbum fidei praedicando committerent.
gold: Among their many evil deeds, which are too numerous to recount, as lamentably chronicled in writing by their historian Gildus, one additional atrocity is that they never made an effort to preach the word of faith to the people of the Saxons or English who were dwelling in the land alongside them.
gpt-4o: Who among other deeds of unspeakable crimes, which their historian Gildas describes in mournful language, also added this, that they would never entrust the word of faith to the Saxon or Anglian people inhabiting Britain with them by preaching.
llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: Who, among other unspeakable wicked deeds, which their historian Gildas describes in a lamentable discourse, added this also, that they never preached the word of faith to the nation of the Saxons or Angles who dwelt with them in Britain.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: Who among other deeds of inexpressible crimes, which the historian Gildas describes in a sorrowful speech, and added that they would never entrust the preaching of the faith to the Saxons or the English who inhabited Britain with them.

sentence: hic, ubi primus hymen, sedes ibi maesta sepulcri: nupta magis dici quam tumulata potes.

Here is the translation:

Here, where the first hymen, the seat of sorrow is there: you can be called a bride rather than a buried one.

sentence: Itaque Graeci, quod ex ea materia iuga iumentis conparant, quod apud eos iuga zyga vocitantur, item zygian eam appellant.

sentence: spes, o nate, meae Tyriarumque unica rerum, Hesperia minitante, salus, terraque fretoque certare Aeneadis, dum stabit vita, memento.

sentence: quas quidem sic ostendendo minui: fessis enim paenitentiaeque plenis animis nostris subici, quo minus cupide repetantur.

sentence: atque utinam rex ipse Noto compulsus eodem adforet Aeneas! equidem per litora certos dimittam et Libyae lustrare extrema iubebo, si quibus eiectus silvis aut urbibus errat.

sentence: Non ego nunc tristis vereor, mea Cynthia, Manes, nec moror extremo debita fata rogo;.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: I am not now truly sorrowful, my Cynthia, nor do I beg the Fates for a prolonged life.

sentence: ictus ut incerto pastoris vulnere serpens erigitur gyro longumque e corpore toto virus in ora legit; paulum si devius hostis torsit iter, cecidere minae tumefactaque frustra colla sedent, irasque sui bibit ipse veneni.
gold: As a snake, without any bias, attacked by a shepherd, spirals up and collects poison from all over its body into the mouth. sentence: cui cum tamen totum ordinem rei ut satisfaciens ex itinere mandassem, vir sanctus et iustus iracundiae meae dedit gloriam, cum nil amplius ego venia postularem, pronuntians more maiorum reos tantae temeritatis iure caesos videri.
gold: Nevertheless, I sent him a complete account of the event while I was still on my journey, with the attitude of one prepared to make amends; and because he was a pious and fair man, he commended my outrage even though I was only seeking forgiveness, stating that in accordance with the traditions of our forefathers, men who were guilty of such neglect appeared to him to be rightfully punished.

gpt-4o-mini: Although I had entrusted the entire order of the matter to him as one satisfying from my journey, the holy and just man gave glory to my anger, since I was asking for no more forgiveness, declaring that the accused of such audacity should be seen as justly slain according to the customs of our ancestors.

sentence: quando obsederis civitatem multo tempore et munitionibus circumdederis ut expugnes eam non succides arbores de quibus vesci potest nec securibus per circuitum debes vastare regionem quoniam lignum est et non homo nec potest bellantium contra te augere numerum
gold: When thou hast besieged a city a long time, and hath compassed it with bulwarks, to take it, thou shalt not cut down the trees that may be eaten of, neither shalt thou spoil the country round about with axes: for it is a tree, and not a man, neither can it increase the number of them that fight against thee.

llama-v3p1-405b-instruct: When you besiege a city for a long time, making war against it to capture it, you shall not destroy its trees by wielding an axe against them. You may eat from them, but you shall not cut them down. Are the trees in the field human, that they should be besieged by you?
gpt-4o-mini: When you have besieged a city for a long time and have surrounded it with fortifications in order to capture it, you shall not cut down trees from which you can eat nor shall you sow destruction in the region with axes, because it is wood and not a man, nor can it increase the number of warriors

sentence: Cum divus Augustus sibi atque urbi Romae templum apud Pergamum sisti non prohibuisset, qui omnia facta dictaque eius vice legis observem, placitum iam exemplum promptius secutus sum, quia cultui meo veneratio senatus adiungebatur.

gold: For one who comes from Gaul, the journey down this road is treacherous due to the sheer incline and overhanging cliffs on either side. Men, animals, and even wagons traverse the road with hesitant steps, sliding forward over the precipitous ravines and treacherous chasms. The only solution to avoid destruction is to bind a number of vehicles together with heavy ropes and have men or oxen hold them back from behind at a very slow pace. In this way, they are able to descend more safely.

sentence: Nam plerosque ex decretis honoribus et alii non receperunt, nemo ante tantus fuit ut crederetur noluisse decerni; quod ego titulis omnibus speciosius reor, quando non trabibus aut saxis nomen tuum sed monimentis aeternae laudis inciditur.

sentence: doctrina oris doctrinam oris audite filii et qui custodierit illam non periet in labiis suis nec scandalizabitur in operibus nequissimis

gpt-4o-mini: Listen, sons, to the teaching of the mouth; and whoever keeps it will not perish in his lips, nor will he be scandalized in wicked deeds.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: The teaching of the mouth, listen to the teaching of the mouth, sons, and he who keeps it will not perish in his lips, nor will he be scandalized in wicked works.

sentence: Quod ergo mortuis litabatur, utique parentationi deputabatur; quae species proinde idololatria est, quoniam et idololatria parentationis est species : tam haec quam illa mortuis ministrat.
gold: What was given to pacify the deceased was considered as a funeral ritual. This type of action is considered as idolatry, as idolatry is also a form of funeral rite; both are a service for the dead.
gpt-4o: Therefore that which is sacrificed to the dead is certainly assigned to the offering for the departed; which type likewise is idolatry, since idolatry is also a type of offering for the departed: just as one, so the other serves the dead.

llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: What was therefore mourned for the dead was assigned to mourning; which kind is therefore idolatry, since idolatry is a species of mourning: both of these serve the dead.

sentence: Ita conviviis eorum et, quod poculis et pytismatis effundetur, simul cadit siccescitque, quique versantur ibi ministrantes, etsi nudis pedibus fuerint, non recipiunt fraces ab eius modi genere pavimenti.

sentence: Ethnici, quos penes nulla est veritatis plenitudo, quia nec doctor veritatis deus, malum et bonum pro arbitrio et libidine interpretantur : alibi bonum quod alibi malum, et alibi malum quod alibi bonum.
gold: The Gentiles do not have complete truth because their teacher of truth is not God. Therefore, they interpret good and evil based on their own judgment and pleasure. Sometimes something that was considered good becomes bad, and the same is true with evil, which can change from bad to good.
gpt-4o: The people, among whom there is no fullness of truth, because they are not taught by the god of truth, interpret good and evil according to their whim and desire: what is good in one place is evil in another, and what is evil in one place is good in another.

gpt-4o-mini: The nations, for whom there is no fullness of truth, because neither is the teacher of truth God, interpret good and evil according to their own judgment and desire: here good which there is evil, and here evil which there is good.
llama-v3p1-8b-instruct: People who have no fullness of truth, because neither the god of truth interprets good and evil at will and whim: elsewhere good that elsewhere is evil, and elsewhere evil that elsewhere is good.

sentence: Omnipotens, solo mentis mihi cognite cultu, ignorate malis et nulli ignote piorum: principio extremoque carens, antiquior aevo, quod fuit aut veniet: cuius formamque modumque nec mens conplecti poterit nec lingua profari:
gold: Almighty One, whom I know through the worship of my heart alone, unknown to the wicked but known to every devout soul, you are without beginning and without end, more ancient than time past and time to come. Your fashion and extent are beyond the grasp of any mind and cannot be expressed by any tongue.

gpt-4o-mini: Almighty, known only by the worship of my mind, ignorant of evils and unknown to none of the pious: lacking a beginning and an end, older than time, which was or will come: whose form and mode neither the mind can comprehend nor the tongue proclaim:

However, after being threatened, he divulged the truth; he was born in Paris, Gaul and served in a cavalry troop, but had deserted to the Persians to evade punishment for a past wrong.
